Aesthetics of Space

The way you arrange the meeting room greatly influences the possibilities and success of your session.  Even spaces that are less than ideal can, with creative attention, be made more beautiful and pleasant.  Optimize the space available to meet your intentions and support the group.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

All Grist for the Mill

Play the ball where it lands.  We aren't in control of what happens, and, handled well, everything that happens—mistakes, off-topic comments, jokes, confusion—is potentially "grist for the mill," available for learning from and using to the group's benefit.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Appreciation

Enthusiasm and thankfulness are infectious; they deepen relationships and trust. A positive approach builds on what's already working. Appreciative reframing converts exhausting struggle into vision and creative energy. Acceptance turns futile confrontation into effective adaptation.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Appropriate Boundaries

Maintain safety and focus for the group by compassionately acknowledging individual suffering in a way that opens the group heart, while at the same time reaffirming the purpose of the group and keeping it on track. Help the group to handle membership questions honestly and holistically.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Balance Process and Content

Content refers to what you are talking about and the results of a session.  Process is how the conversation happens.  Like two wings of a bird, both are needed for balance, lift and progress.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Balance Structure and Flexibility

Process structures, such as a clear agenda or requesting participants to raise hands, can help create safety, focus, and a form for the group's energy to pour into.  Yet to sustain the life of a group, this must be balanced with a great openness to change, dancing between the two as needed.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Breaking Bread Together

People gathered over a meal is one of the most ancient forms of community process.  Sharing food together forges bonds, affirming our common humanity.  Nourished bodies and relationships enhance the overall quality of the shared time and collective work.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Celebrate

Publicly celebrate milestones, accomplishments and recurring events. This builds relationship and identity, helps groups affirm shared history, unifies our stories and common goals, and expresses joy.  Can be planned and ritualized, or as spontaneous as a group cheer.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Challenge

NEW DRAFT May 11 (Dave):

Challenging accepted wisdom, ideas, information, processes or perspectives can provoke learning and new thinking, surmount complacency and blind spots, and engender creativity. It can also force us to reexamine our uncritical acceptance of convention and the status quo.

 

Blind spots, ignorance and conformity easily go unnoticed.  Likewise, we can become habituated to comfort, privilege, and the status quo.  To provoke growth and improve conditions, we can disturb business as usual and engage creatively with disturbances.

EDIT:  Make sure this pattern is sufficiently constructively framed. Start with more uplifting/positive "to provoke..."

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Circle

A circle is a safe, solid, yet permeable space with an inside, a moving focus, and an outside. It is a welcoming shape where everyone can see and hear each other and every voice is equal. It creates a field that invites sharing and story.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Closing

The Closing is part of the whole energy cycle of a group process. It is the formal ritual that concludes the time and space started in the Opening and Welcome.  It completes the time together and ushers in a shift to what follows.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Commitment

 

Aligning our energy with an effort we value helps us live in and for something larger than our small selves.  A group's potency increases with the commitment of its members, especially when those commitments are explicit and then fulfilled.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Common Ground

Consciously deciding to focus more attention on where we agree than where we don’t.  By tuning in to what we share, we find the way to make progress together.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Courageous Modelling

Someone needs to be willing to risk going first: to speak out, try a new behaviour, raise concerns, hear feedback, and so on.  Courageous Modelling is about being honest, authentic and bold.  It catalyzes forward movement by taking the lead and showing others it can be done, and how.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Deliberate

We reflect on the issues we are here to understand and decide about as well as on our own functioning.  Done well, thinking things over together helps us understand a bigger picture, so we can deal creatively and well with changing realities.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Discharging

Before shift can happen, we need to acknowledge and let go of what's present, especially emotionally.  This sometimes happens directly, as when we make space in a meeting to express tough feelings like anger, frustration, or despair.  Other times it happens indirectly, through humour or taking a walk.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Distilling

There comes a time in the conversation or inquiry when it helps to summarize and synthesis what has been said or learned.  Articulate the common ground of meaning.  Assess what it all adds up to.  Distill elements to an essential, integrated whole.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Dive In

Sometimes, especially when the way ahead is unclear, choosing to just begin and try things out is the best way to approach the challenge, task or issue at hand.  With a commitment to see what happens, diving in helps us discover a path ahead.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Divergence and Convergence Rhythm

Diverging we widen perspective, explore new terrain and open up options.  In converging we zero in on the thinking that coalesces collective wisdom and leads toward focused decision-making.  Good group process involves a natural cycling between these, including thoughtfulness about which to engage when.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Dwell with Emotions

Simply allowing emotions to be expressed and acknowledged, without jumping in to "fix" or change them.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Embrace Dissonance and Difference

Encourage a group to sit with contradictory viewpoints and the uncertainty and ambiguity this can bring.  Acknowledge all viewpoints as equally valid, and engage with them, especially when tensions are high and agreement seems far away.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Emergence

NEW DRAFT May/11 (Dave):

Emergence is the result of an empowered self-organizing group creating conditions for and co-evolving a complex, collective product of its ideas, learning, experiences, feelings and visions, without too strong an attachment to what the outcome will be. The group allows this product to emerge, cultivates it, lets it come, gives birth to it.

 

Emergence arises from an empowered group pouring out its ideas, experiences, feelings and visions, without too strong an attachment to what the outcome will be. Between rigid structure and unproductive chaos, numbing familiarity and paralyzing anxiety, emergence embraces complexity to create a collective midwifery that can be brilliant, even amazing.

EDIT: capture idea of co-evolution, edge zones, omit "brilliant...amazing", add how we cultivate it, self-organization, adaptation, emergent learning, allowing, diff from bal struct & flexibility, creating conditions for it.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Experts on Tap

Experts play excellent supporting roles providing technical help and judgments based on specific training. These skills and information are valuable as one of the many resources to draw on, but groups ultimately empower themselves, using their expertise as local stakeholders to deliberate and make decisions about issues affecting them.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Expressive Arts

The arts take participants out of the linear, rational, intellectual realm into a more creative, emotional, intuitive and holistic one.  Performing, hearing and watching arts such as music, skits, dance, improv, and poetry [ 43 ] can move, engage and inspire a group, and even result in Viewpoint Shift.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Feedback

Feedback is offering and receiving information in various forms that enables adaptation and learning. Feedback lets us know what is working and what is not, helping us stay on track for achieving our goals.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Follow the Energy

Following the Energy means letting our observation of the group's cues and "vibe" guide our response and steering of topics and process.  By paying attention to where the life is, we help it flower.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Fractal

Phenomena tend to repeat at a variety of scales.  The same dynamic may occur within one person, between an individual and the group, within a subgroup or the group as a whole, and between the group and other groups or larger wholes it is related to.  Astute group members observe patterns at one level and use this insight to make changes at another level.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Gaia

The presence of nature in group process activities—natural settings, artifacts etc.—reminds us of our place in the world. It grounds us and gives us perspective, inspiration and beauty. It reminds us we are one small part of a very large whole, always connected.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Generate Possibilities

Groups commonly need to spawn fresh ideas.  Creative approaches include brainstorming, play, improvisation, art, and more, each with its own rules and logic.  Learn what supports genuinely novel inspiration and adaptation and put it to use.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Go Deeper

Recognizing and attending to what calls out for more intensive exploration.  Taking the time to unpack comments, drill down into issues, peel back the layers, delve further into underlying dynamics or feelings—all in search of the crux of what matters most.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Go Meta

 

Sometimes we need to be aware of HOW we're doing what we're doing -- of dysfunctional group dynamics, unacknowledged cultural influences, repressed voices, and soon. At that point we need to step out of the content of our conversation and address our process.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Good Faith Assumptions

By assuming good intent on the part of others, we increase trust and effectiveness.  Instead of interpreting a perceived "negative" action as an attempt at manipulation, insult, or power-play, we explain it as unskillful action and/or search for underlying needs in common.  Searching for a better story, we find or create one.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Group Culture

Groups tend to develop their own culture over time, based on knowledge, beliefs, practices and behaviours its members share. A shared culture can build trust, cohesion, and a sense of safety among the members, thus furthering their collaboration.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Guerrilla Facilitation

Guerilla facilitation arises in gatherings with no formal leadership structures or when designated facilitators are floundering or inadequate.  Any participant might sense how to advance a group process by stepping up and constructively intervening in the moment.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Harvesting

Collecting and disseminating what has been said, done, debated, decided, left undecided, or agreed upon as next steps. Recording the "collective memory" of the event.  The harvest is what you hold in your hands when the process is complete.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

History and Context

The history, context, and setting hugely influence how the rest of the patterns are invoked.  Convenors tune in to discern what people coming might expect, where the existing culture can be stretched and where it must be respected as is.  The best sessions often combine sufficient familiarity to connect along with something new reaching toward fresh possibilities.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Holding Space

Opening and holding open the psychological and spiritual space of trust, safety and focus within which the group shares, debates, resolves, learns, co-creates, and and finally converges on consensus, decision and action towards its intended purpose.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Honour Each Person

Respect each person's essential human dignity.  View their uniqueness as a resource for group wisdom.  Tolerate and even embrace people's quirks because each person brings gifts to the whole, gifts that become available as the person feels seen and respected.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Hosting

Helping the session feel like "home."  Making the place and arrangements comfortable for everyone supports accomplishment of the group's work.  Attend to the well-being of each person and the whole.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Improvise

An offering based in one's perception of emerging circumstances, combined with inner promptings, at its best resulting in just what’s needed in the moment.  May refer to anything from a proposed format shift to a witty remark, and anything else spontaneous that helps the whole group be creative and adaptive.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Inform the Group Mind

We gather facts, feelings and perspectives that reveal and deepen the group's awareness of itself and its world.  The most helpful information comes from diverse sources and is accurate, relevant, accessible, and compelling.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Inquiry

We choose to cultivate a curious attitude.  As one specific expression of this, great questions frame, provoke, and open us to new ideas. Many successful methods have repeated questions at their core, such as: "What's at the heart of the matter?" "If you were czar, what would you do?" "What is possible now?" What's the most powerful question we could ask right now?

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Invitation

The Invitation brings people together.  It expresses a clear call toward shared purpose, tuned to get the right people into the room with shared intent.  It lets people know why this is important and what to expect, while requesting the honour of their presence.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Iteration

Exploring successively deeper levels leads to greater understanding and potentially more appropriate action, as the results from the first round inform the second.  Repeat a process multiple times in the moment, or revisit an issue at a later time for more powerful effect.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Letting Go

Before we can be present, first we must let go of our attachments and our preconceived notions, and be open to outcomes.  As individuals we seek to allow whatever needs to manifest through us to come through—sourced in instinct or "Spirit”—in order to be of service to ourselves, group, and the world, free from unhelpful influence from one's ego or fears.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Listening

Listening weaves people together and frees energy.  Listen from genuine curiosity, welcoming the sharing of feelings, ideas and perspectives.  When we listen with our whole selves to more than the words, people feel heard and their energy starts flowing into new channels.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Magic

At certain moments, something beyond the group may emerge, accompanied by a sense of awe and mystery . . . and resulting in a unanimous feeling of astonished accomplishment.  Conditions inviting it include shared passion, urgency, openness, energy and trust—yet the quality is always mysterious, never guaranteed.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Mapping and Measurement

Take time to show what has happened or what's ahead.  Skillful use of record-keeping, timelines, graphs, murals, videos, etc., not only direct our attention and help us make sense of our experience, but enable us to share it with people who weren't there and to make informed decisions.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Mirroring

Mirroring is one way let people know that you have heard them.  When the essence of what we say and share is offered back to us empathically, we feel genuinely listened to, heard and appreciated. This can heal relationships, end stuck places/periods, and open steps forward.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Mode Choice

Many routes lead to a desired outcome.  Strategically shifting modalities—perhaps from a dialogue circle to a roleplay—energizes participants, deepens learning, and advances the work of the group.  A mix of methodologies that simultaneously or over the course of the gathering access different ways of knowing, such as visual, auditory and kinesthetic, also enrich the process.

 

PROPOSAL:  Change name to Mode Choice, new heart draft as follows:

Instead of defaulting to general discussion, consider what mode of interaction—visual, auditory or kinesthetic, formal or informal, fast or slow—is the best fit to support the group in reaching its intention.  Strategically shifting formats energizes participants, accesses different ways of knowing, and advances the work.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Moving toward Alignment

To act jointly, we journey from disparate places to a coherent, shared sense of what's real, what's needed and what we will do to accomplish it.  Group alignment emerges through conversations generating shared understandings, stories, and decisions.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Naming

To call out, to state directly what is perceived.  Naming can function to "birth" things not yet recognized by the group, sometimes things that are taboo.  Akin to an alchemical process, to name can be to transform, and naming brings change in its wake.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Nooks in Space and Time

The incubation of Individual creativity and relationship-building occurs most effectively and fruitfully at the edges of a group.  Private space and time for solo musings and open-ended conversation may be designed in by facilitators or found by group members seeking their own unconstrained opportunities.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Not about You

Separate what is being said or suggested from the person who said it. Leaving the baggage of interpersonal relationships and disagreements at the door, consider ideas on their own merits. Work on the same side together against the problem or challenge.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Opening and Welcome

The opening and welcome set the tone.  Begin intentionally, in a manner that invites group members to connect with one another, enter their voice into the circle and participate as their authentic selves.  Attend to building excitement, focus and commitment for the work to come.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Playfulness

Play in a group context, is a purposeful, structured way to engage topics and issues, often leading to richer understanding and expanded visions of what is possible.  Light-hearted and high-spirited interaction exercises mind, senses, imagination and body, engendering creativity and deepening relationships.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Power of Constraints

Embrace limitations and boundaries as a source of inspiration.  Until you appreciate the obstacles, you can't see your way to overcoming and adapting to them.  Once you have accepted constraints, they can morph into useful forms that open up new possibilities, spurring creativity.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Power of Place

The location, setting, and beauty of the site for an event can have a major impact on the group's energy, attentiveness and and ability to connect.  Choose a place that is the right fit for your intention.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Power Shift

Critical awareness and transparency around existing power differences can, if held well, allow the group to adapt authority structures to best take advantage of the gifts and perspectives of everyone involved, valuing input from all members regardless of status.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Preparedness

Think ahead and anticipate what might happen. Be ready for it. Do this before the event and in your ongoing alert attention. Do what you can so the right people, resources, awareness and attitudes are present, as needed, to help the session be smooth and effective.

 

[heart needs to be rewritten: It's about setting the stage, creating the desired gathering/engagement. Includes contracting, agenda-building and advanced research. That is, not so much about just planning for avoidance!]


 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Presence

Presence is deep listening, total attention, sharing in, and being fully open to and connected with what is happening in the moment. It is bringing one's full self and focus to the here and now.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Priority Focus

Keeping the group's energies, pace and trajectory appropriate to achieving its stated intention and purpose, by helping it set and stick to its priorities, and sometimes shift what's most important to the group.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Purpose

Purpose is the destination we choose from a sea of possibilities.  Shared purpose calls us together and focuses us, evolving as understanding deepens.  It gives impetus and energy to our work: when we're connected with genuine purpose, energy flows and things happen.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Reflection-Action Cycle

Consider.  Enact.  Debrief.  Experiment further.  Effective processes that move groups forward often involve iterative cycles of reflection, followed by action, leading to additional reflection, and so on.  Alternating between action and reflection fosters engagement and integration, deepens experiential learning, and promotes adaptive problem-solving.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Rest

People use unscheduled times for rest, reflection, integration, and nurturing important social connections.  Building sufficient "down time" into group process yields better overall results, too, as participants return to group sessions renewed and often with new insights and ideas.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Right Size Bite

How much is too much?  How much is too little? Find the appropriate "chunks" to work with in this moment, this session, this whole process.  Split complex topics and tasks into pieces that support people's continued successful engagement. 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Ritual

Ritual is ceremony—it is primal, and connects, honours and grounds the group; it may also mark opening, transition, cycles, milestones or closing. Ritual is also the formal or habitual repetition of intentional practices that have proved their value.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Seasoned Timing

 

When is the right time to propose an idea, to try something new in a conflict, to switch processes or bring in an outside expert or facilitator? When to stick with or diverge from the agenda (if there is one)? Sense the timing of things to swim with the flow and not against it.  Be patient and alert for ripeness.  When the time is right, act.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Seeing the Forest, Seeing the Trees

Shepherding a group discussion includes attending to when the group needs a wider view  vs. when it needs to drill down into the details.  Zoom out to see vision, patterns, and overall trends; zoom in for examples, specific data, and other particulars.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Self-Awareness

Self-awareness means knowing who you really are:  your values, needs, biases, and more.  This knowledge helps both individuals and groups in a process engage effectively with those around them.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Setting Intention

Setting Intention envisions and names what will be done to reach toward or achieve the purpose of the group.  It reminds us of our responsibilities, guiding us to actions that fulfill the purpose for which a gathering was called.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Shared Airtime

Everyone deserves to be heard, and everyone has a piece of the truth. We find ways to invite sharing from all, not just the loudest, most senior or most articulate, and to draw out the wisdom of reflective or hesitant participants.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Shared Leadership and Roles

Rotate facilitators.  Trade off note taking.  Let a voice at the margin take center stage.  Distributing leadership increases participation and taps the gifts of all group members.  Sharing power and collective responsibility for the whole nurtures equity and empowerment, while increasing ownership and investment.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Silence

Silence:  the rests between that make the music.  A moment to tune into yourself or the group, to pause for transition or deepening.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Simplify

A simple process allows you to stay focused on your purpose. A clear understanding of your purpose allows you to do what is needed, no more, no less. Include only the details that are significant, so participants will understand what is and is not important.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Spirit

NEWER: Working with Spirit means inviting the deeper forces of the universe to be with us as co-creators of the good. Bringing in this wider perspective reminds us of what's most important and provides wisdom, inspiration, and support.

 

OLD:  Spirit is the indefinable quality that enables a group to work passionately, with intention and flow, seemingly without effort. When spirit shows up, wonderful things happen. And no amount of money, technology, process or talent can make up for its absence.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Story pattern

All communication involves the sharing of stories, metaphors, and myths in order to  convey complex ideas, context, meaning and nuance that simple data cannot. By telling our own personal stories we build trust and connection, encourage imagination, and express the essence of who we are. By telling cultural stories we connect ourselves to the experience of others and interact with whole systems.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Subgroup and Whole Group

Small subgroups are ideal for involving all participants, doing specific tasks and offers a safer space for sharing.  Convening in the whole group provides context, meaning and convergence at critical junctures.  Strategically shifting between the two takes advantage of their complementary natures, furthering a group's process and purpose.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Taking Responsibility

This pattern keeps a group connected with its own power, both collectively and individually.  Combating the tendencies to blame, scapegoat, and otherwise play the victim, we keep the source of action present in the room.  Regardless of who did what, when, let us ask, "What can we do here and now?"

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Tend Relationships

We take care of each other in order to reach the goals we are striving for—to get there in one piece, together.  When we get too focused on product, the work suffers in the end; Tending Relationships helps redress the balance, sustaining organizations and movements for the long haul.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Time Shift

Time Shifting invites people to consider events and possibilities from the perspective of either the past or the future, in order to change their assumptions about what is possible in the present. 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Trajectory

Embarking on a group session is a collective journey. How long will it take, and what will be the shape of the time togther?  Structuring an agenda in light of anticipated stages along the path, and choosing activities that align with each phase, helps us complete the arc and arrive at our desired destination. 

 

[old Developmental Time Frame heart to incorporate here as beneficial]

There is more to an event than what happens directly during it.  Tracking and coordinating related activities that start before, or end after, ensures that the activities of the event contribute effectively to achieving both that event's intention and a larger purpose.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Translation

Translation forms a bridge of understanding from one person or group to another.  It supports overcoming barriers caused by differences in social standing, culture, life experiences, communication skills, or lack of shared language.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Transparency

Transparency means being open about what's real: feelings, experiences, how decisions get made, finances, and more.  It's about taking action in a direct and honest way, believing that the free flow of information will build trust.  Handled well, Transparency builds connection and community.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Trust the Wisdom of the Group

When the path is uncertain, seek intelligence, direction, and intuition from the collective.  No matter what the stuck point, with patience and good listening a group can almost always generate the options it needs.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Unity and Diversity

Holding simultaneous awareness of both what we share or are in common, and our uniquenesses.   Sometimes it is most important for a group to honour the distinctions and hear the differences; other times it is crucial to focus on that which binds us together.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Value the Margins

In evolution, the edge between ecosystems is fertile ground for adaptation.  Similarly in group dynamics, sometimes the most growth comes from generative disturbances at the margins, in the form of alien ideas or people we aren't as comfortable with.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Viewpoint Shift

Viewpoint Shift is about stepping from my usual way of seeing things into another, in order to understand someone else, shift energy, and open up new ideas. 

 

EDIT:  Merge in info from Time Shifting and Reframing.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Whole System in the Room

Gathering a cross-section of the organization or community leads to coordinated visions, innovative problem-solving, more informed choices and quicker implementation of changes.  A critical mass of decision-makers and diverse stakeholders working together sees and deepens interconnections, helping the whole system adapt and learn more effectively.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Witness with Compassion

Focusing your attention on what is happening, rather than on your reaction to it or judgements.  From a grounded inner place, with presence and neutrality, listening and watching with empathy.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Yes, and

NEW DRAFT May 11 (Dave):

Constructively building upon or adding to what someone else has just said, done or proposed. This encourages, reinforces and provides momentum for a deepening of understanding and appreciation, or for movement in a new direction.

 

The "yes, and..." process of encouraging and enabling collective understanding and collaboration by agreeing with and constructively adding to what someone else in the group has just said, done or proposed.
